content.description: A nice TR and fun to do if you have the gear anchor set up from One Hard Move. Start just right of the horizontal for One Hard Move on small holds. Work you way up the dish using pinches, slopers, crimps, and some nice technique to push your way to the lip.
content.location: Starts either on the stone fence or just right of it

content.description: The main large crack on the large wall. Easy and dirty start, one steep and painful handjam crux to a cruiser finish. Could probably be lead strait up avoiding the crux/diagonal crack but would be really dirty and much easier.
content.location: right most route on the tall wall, shares anchors.

content.description:
This climb was done a long time ago by someone who put in one 1/4 inch bolt to pro the whole climb. Pinch your way past the first bolt to a decent stance with a hand jam on the way, head strait up to the next bolt, pass an undercling/sidepull then mantle left of the third bolt and run up to the anchors. If you stay right of the third bolt and avoid the jug out left it goes at 10d. 

  A bit run out on top, make sure the belayer pays attention here.
Sweet warmup climb for the cliff. Has some monster holds and great feet to a cruxy mantle move before the climbing mellows way out(a bit runout but 5.3ish).
content.protection: small to medium cams. shares anchors with the sport climbs to the right
content.location: left most route on the tall wall, starts in the obvious crack system.

content.description: This climb is a bit longer than One Step Forward since the beginning is a diagonal crack and the finish zigs off to the right(crux), then left at the end to the shared anchor. Slightly contrived to keep the grade at 5.9, if you end up finishing One Step Forward the grade is 5.7.
content.protection: two bolts. gear can be used to get to the first bolt and gear can be used to finish the climb(.75-#1) but is not necessary.
content.location: Starts 30 feet right(officially) of One Step Forward near the stone fence in the diagonal crack.

content.description: Left-most route on the slabby wall. About 30(?) feet left of the stone wall. Climb up a small crack system to the bolt and a nice stance. Smear past the bolt to some gear and then to the anchor. Possibly the most slabby move in CT at the grade.
content.protection: small and medium cams(tricams?), one bolt(crux), anchors
content.location: left most route on the wall

content.description: Name and FA unknown... Start on the stone wall in the large horizontal. Step up and undercling the sweet pinch, get your feet up some more, slap for a small slopey crimp on the right of the rounded corner. Make a desperate throw out left  for the high horizontal, stick it, hold the swing, and match the flake to the right of the horizontal, reach up to the high pocket on the right side and get outta there!
Fun climb with a tricky roof move. Probably the hardest lead at the cliff.
content.protection: 3 bolts. some people bring cams(#1-#2camalots) for the finish which is a little runout but only 5.4. shares anchor with rusty and radtrad. Caution should be used at the anchor, a large carabiner clipped directly into the bolt might lever out on it. either girth hitch some webbing through the bolts or clip into the quick links to avoid this.
content.location: shares the first bolt of Rusty Oldtimer

content.description:
This is a short route on steep terrain. Start by climbing the broken ledge to the first bolt. Clip the second bolt and get into the business. Climb the gray and orange bulge. 

  Despite the route's lack of length, it can be surprisingly pump.
content.location: From the parking lot walk down the Blue trail road until you come to the Blue/Orange (not Blue/Red as mentioned elsewhere) trail marked by tree blazes and a sign. Follow the Blue/Orange trail to the base of the cliff. (this is significantly shorter than walking to Feather Ledges)

content.description: This is the shortest route at the cliff but feels like a full on climb. Sustained  dificulty on this climb. Great place to set up an anchor for the right side of the arete(tr#4).
content.protection: small cams, possibly a small stopper. gear anchor(#3cam) or walk off.
content.location: same start as the second climb, left of the stone fence, go strait up the left side of the arete to the right of the water streak.

content.description: Starts approximately 15 feet right of TBD. Start up the vertical quartz section, climb through awkward flakes and underclings up to a cedar tree. Fun climbing but a little dirty and a little hard to find bomber gear. Crux is the first 15 ft.
content.protection: Cams and some sling for an anchor at the top.
content.location: right most climb on the crag. 15 feet to the right of the fat TBD crack.

content.description:
Small crag near Chatfield with some quality routes in the 5.9 range. Nice and sheltered for winter climbing, shady enough in the summer to climb as well. Mostly southeast/southwest facing.  

  This is a great crag to hit in the winter, its very footwork intensive climbing where you can place some gear, clip some bolts and keep your head in the game for leading. 

  cams from a 0/purple metolius to a #3 camalot are useful.
